title: 104_hr3992
content: The Act may be cited as the "Medicare Commission Act of 1996" and establishes the Medicare Commission. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program, also known as the Commission, is established with 15 members appointed by the President, Senate Majority Leader, and Speaker of the House of Representatives. The House of Representatives, in consultation with the Minority Leader, will appoint members to the Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program. Appointments must be made within 3 months of the Act's enactment, and members serve for the life of the Commission. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission will hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed and will meet at the Chairman's call. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for meetings. The Commission shall select a Chairman from among its members. The Commission shall select a Chairman from among its members. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with reviewing analyses of the current and long-term financial condition of the Medicare trust funds, identifying potential threats to their solvency, analyzing solutions to ensure financial integrity and health benefits, and providing recommendations to the Secretary of Health and Human Services, the President, and Congress to preserve the trust funds' long-term solvency. The Commission established under the Social Security Act is required to submit a report to the President and Congress within 12 months. Congressional leaders must introduce legislation within 3 months of the report's submission to ensure the long-term solvency of the Medicare trust funds. Legislation introduced under the Social Security Act must be voted upon within 3 months in the House of Representatives and the Senate to ensure the long-term solvency of the Medicare trust funds. If not voted upon, the legislation will be considered highly privileged for further consideration. If legislation introduced under the Social Security Act is not voted upon in the Senate within 3 months, any committee to which it was referred will be discharged, and a motion to proceed with the legislation will be privileged. If no vote on the legislation is taken within 3 months, it will be considered privileged for consideration in the Senate. If legislation introduced under the Social Security Act is not voted upon in the Senate within 3 months, it will be considered privileged for consideration in the Senate. If not voted on in the House of Representatives within 3 months, a joint resolution endorsing the recommendations in the report under subsection (b) and providing legislative authority to carry out such recommendations can be moved. The Commission established by the Act has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services. Additionally, the Commission has authority over personnel matters. The Commission members who are federal government officers or employees serve without additional compensation. Private citizens on the Commission also serve without pay, but are reimbursed for travel expenses while conducting Commission business. The Chairman of the Commission can appoint an executive director and necessary personnel without following civil service laws. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can provide administrative support. The Chairman can set compensation without adhering to certain pay regulations. The Chairman of the Commission can appoint an executive director and necessary personnel without following civil service laws. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Chairman may procure temporary services at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting its report. Expenses will be covered by funds available to the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
